pros: Easy Tasks and know what to expect
cons: Low Pay and it’s almost necessary to work overtime

job_title: Mental Health Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: flexible shifts and hours, structure in terms of patient activities.
cons: Poor management. worst food in the cafeteria. always short staffed. low pay rate for your experience and dedication. management does not value their staff. High turn over. always hiring because people are always leaving, No growth opportunities. Too much politics.

pros: Facility was a 10 min drive to home so i took the job , not worth it
cons: pay is low, management/supervisors were out to get you, very micromanaged, throw under the bus mentality, zero support and training, entirely terrible experience

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Atlanta, GA
pros: The shifts are convenient as its 7-3, 3-11 and 11-7 and 12hr shifts in the weekends.
cons: while I worked there, the place was always dirty and extremely short staffed in the weekends. Housekeeping do not do there jobs in the weekends because they were under paid. Management are not understanding and do not listen to the needs of there staff. staff members are nothing but numbers. There is no chances for growth there. staff get pennies added to there pay at the end of the year.

job_title: MHA (Mail Handler Assistant ) in Atlanta, GA
pros: You build a good bond with staff
cons: Management doesn’t appreciate staff members

job_title: BHT-behavioral Health Tech in Dunwoody, GA
pros: Truly, there was nothing positive about this role.
cons: The lives of the residents in this hospital depended on people who had 0 qualifications and little to no training on the actual role they would be performing. We spent days on boarding and in orientation only to be presented with an absolute nightmare of tasks once in the department. The doctors and nurses treated the patients horribly. I could go on..

pros: Free supervision and that’s really all I can think of.
cons: Overworked and underpaid. High Turnover.

review_title: Management is unequipped for the challenge.
job_title: Needs Assessment Counselor in Atlanta, GA
pros: Some of the people are wonderful. Great starter job. You will see every psychiatric emergency imaginable. Good benefits, but they are costly. If you work at Peachford for any length of time, you will be prepared to work any job in psych.
cons: Poor management. Non confrontational. Punishes the entire department for one person’s mistake. Reactive, not proactive. Communication is poorly handled.

job_title: Mental Health Associate in Atlanta, GA
pros: Patients and coworkers are lovely
cons: Adminstration doesnt care about staff more about profit and getting patients in and out

review_title: Too many chiefs and no Indians
pros:
Four days a week Monday through Thursday
Decent benefits
Eight short hours
cons:
3 to 11 And 11 to 7 supervisors are bullies And Don't like to be corrected when they are wrong. 
Too much micromanaging from the top to the bottom.
More gossiping than elementary school And the leadership are the worst Gossipers

job_title: Mental Health Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Flexible schedules and decent pay
cons: There could be workplace drama if you don’t mind your business. If you keep to yourself respectfully and help out without having to be asked you’ll be fine.

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Atlanta, GA
pros: UHS has good benefits if you are able to go full time. Peachford offers incentives for taking on shifts that are up for grabs
cons: Can be high stress working in the juvenile unit

job_title: Mental Health Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: You will always be able to work
cons: the whole company is run poorly. Employees underpaid = no motivation, group therapy is run by MHA's with no prior experience of being a therapist (none of the group therapy is run by licensed therapists). In training, you are not taught how mental disorders present themselves which can put employees who do not have a degree in mental health related fields at a huge disadvantage. You are also contacted constantly to come in and work. The hospital is a revolving door type place.

pros: you meet some staff that are really cool, down to earth, friendly, and knowledgeable
cons: management sucks and are completely unsupportive of clinical personnel. on occasion when we are so short-staffed that supervisors have to work on the unit, they are comically inept. the pay is terrible. peachford hires contract nurses through an agency that pays far more an hour than a full-time position at peachford pays. that really messes with morale and causes a very high turnover rate. the hospital is filthy and archaic. computers run off of windows 2014. ekg machines are from the early 90s. there's dust and grime everywhere. don't get trapped here, it's a very toxic environment. find somewhere else where your skills and experience are appreciated and well-compensated.

pros: The coworkers are AMAZING. You become family. You have the ability to positively impact peoples lives. 32 hours is considered full-time with benefits.
cons: This is a great learning hospital. But long term, the pay is terrible and the acuity acceptance is so much worse than they like to make it seem. They worry so much about making money they don’t care about taking aggressive or inappropriate patients. Ps- it’s a restraint free hospital

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Atlanta, GA
pros: The people you work with are great and understandable
cons: Low pay not worth for how put you do

pros: Good management, supportive coworkers and the managers try to use every opportunity to celebrate their staff.
cons: It’s still a difficult field to work in no matter what. Staff shortages and poor pay for unlicensed personnel attribute to staff shortages.

job_title: Mental Health Assistant in Dunwoody, GA
pros: Great experience working with the kids, Plenty of overtime available.
cons: Constantly inadequately staffed. Not enough pay. They will overwork you if you let them. Management will only speak with you when something is done wrong and never compliment you when you're doing something right (negative reinforcement). This place will literally have one MHA with 50 adolescents and two nurses, which is extremely dangerous and illegal. It's supposed to be a 5:1 ratio. Lots of favoritism and discrimination. Rebecca Hayes, who runs the hospital, seems to enjoy bullying, antagonizing and belittling her staff. You will run an entire unit by yourself and she will make you feel like you're nothing. Not worth it.

pros: Great for new graduates in the field to gain valuable knowledge and experience.
cons: The salary is below industry standards

pros: There were no pros; this place was a nightmare
cons: Treated patients horrible, minimal training

pros: Free supervision is pretty nice
cons: Toxic work environment is bad

Overtime

Pay

pros: You can basically make your own hours
cons: The raises are not high.

pros: Co workers usually work great together.

cons: Some apathetic and jaded coworkers, understaffed

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Dunwoody, GA
pros: So much overtime available -if you could work 24 hours would let you

Short staffed 
No movement

job_title: Mental Health Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: My coworkers were great. Most were about the patients and tried to help whenever possible.
cons: Not enough positive reinforcement from management and not enough resources to do the job sometimes.

review_title: Company does not look out for it's employees
job_title: Mental Health Technician in Dunwoody, GA
pros: There are no pros about this job
cons: Long hours, short staff, no security or safety for employees

pros: Flexible Hours if you work PRN hours
cons: Management not supportive, poor staffing, lots of turnover

job_title: Mental Health Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great experience in an inpatient psychiatric setting.
cons: Hourly rate isn't great.. Or deserved. Can be a challenging and hard job and isn't recognized as such. From MHA there isn't any growth unless you're a nursing student or considering going back to school to be a nurse.

review_title: Peachford is a fair place to work that provides a necessary service, but it values its employees little
pros: Nurses at peachford get to develop meaningful relationships with patients and other staff members. PRN staff are fairly compensated and it is easy to get shifts.
cons: The nurse to patient ratio is terrible. I have seen 42:1. Upper level management is incompetent and have no drive or leadership qualities at all.

job_title: Mental Health Associate in Atlanta, GA
pros: Some of the people I worked with on the unit, and being able to make a difference
cons: They do not treat their employees with respect unless you are one of the chosen few, day shift always came in late, I worked here for many years as a PRN staff and did not receive one raise, they do not care about their employees

review_title: I have been working at Peachford hospital as a nurse for nearly 4 years
pros: It is a good place to work.
cons: Low pay rates, except for the CPI and CPR classes, no other routine in services given. Most in services are done through emails of late. Not effective. Does not give staff, especially the nurses ample training hours.

job_title: Mental Health Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great staff! A 24/7 mental health facility. Recognizes works for achievements.
cons: There are several nurses whom are lazy (but many great ones). Many times the staff is cancelled and several admissions come and we are under staffed. However there are TONS of PRN workers than can be used, whom are always looking for hours.

review_title: Great place for mental health professionals
job_title: Direct Support Professional in Dunwoody, GA
pros: I have enjoyed my time at the Peach.  I like being focused on behavioral health and I like having a say
cons: Because of the reputation of the hospital in the community, the hospital is usually full and therefore very busy but makes the shift go by quick.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Competitive pay
Possibility for 8 hour Mon-Fri schedule. 
Decent benefits
cons:
Patients are kept inpatient based on how long insurance will pay, and are regularly misinformed as to when they will be able to leave.
Poorly Staffed
Inconsistent management
Frequent staff injuries from violent patients
Very poor communication

job_title: Mental Health Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Not much to say about pros other than it was a job that helped to pay the bills.They have good health insurance.
cons: Unsafe work environment. Staff shortages and no on site security to help with medicating or restraining the violent patients that come through on a daily basis.

pros: It's okay, I guess...  For the most part, I manage my own work-load and schedule.
cons: It is a 24/7 hospital environment, so I.T. and/or applications issues require fixing very quickly, which means after hours, weekends, and holiday calls.

pros: Great benefits, organized structure, strong leadership in the field, great training facility for upcoming and non licensed professionals, strong physicians and nurses.
cons: Pay could improve based on the high acuity population of clients. Sometimes feels like a revolving door because of the turnover. If you like larger corporate feel, this is a great place.

pros: Coworkers are high performing, program has quality, experience is valuable, free licensing supervision, patients are appreciative
cons: Low pay ($17/hr), management is unappreciative, workload is very heavy

pros: Great learning experience. You will gain a lot of clinical knowledge. Great team environment. Very good for recent grads to gain knowledge of acute care patients.
cons: Can be intense dealing with acute care patients. Long hours. Stressful at times.

job_title: Mental Health Assistant in Dunwoody, GA
pros: Get experience in your field / major

- pay is too low for what the position requires

- Management does not care about trying to make changes to help staff and patient safety.
- a lot of the staff does not know what their doing. 
- management very rude and unprofessional 
- no room for growth unless you are trying to become a nurse.

pros: Excellent care provided to the patients and the management team really cares about the quality of care and the staff
cons: It can be an emotionally tough envoirment to work in, but the support system of peers is great!

pros: I enjoy patient care and leadership
cons: Increase of stress and headaches

pros: flexibility in PRN schedule; and its a job in hard times
